articles.headline: Big Insurers Send a Wake-Up Call to Hedge Fund Investors
articles.snippet: The high-reward, low-risk promises of hedge funds failed to materialize, and many insurance companies are unwinding their positions.
articles.abstract: The high-reward, low-risk promises of hedge funds failed to materialize, and many insurance companies are unwinding their positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many sophisticated investors, the nation’s largest insurers drank the hedge fund Kool-Aid, pouring billions into the high-fee investment funds and helping drive hedge fund assets to over $3 trillion.

articles.headline: Minnesota Law School, Facing Waning Interest, Cuts Admissions
articles.snippet: By shrinking enrollment, and taking in less tuition income, the University of Minnesota hopes to preserve its national standing as a top law school.
articles.abstract: By shrinking enrollment, and taking in less tuition income, the University of Minnesota hopes to preserve its national standing as a top law school.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — On a recent rainy spring day, students and professors at the University of Minnesota Law School looked ahead to year-end exams and May 14 graduation as they bustled between classes. But behind the academic routine, Minnesota’s administration, as at other law schools across the country, was striving to respond to the public’s growing disinterest in law careers.

articles.headline: Facebook, Facing Bias Claims, Shows How Editors and Algorithms Guide News
articles.snippet: Accused of political bias, the company offered details on how human editors and algorithms choose what appears — or doesn’t appear — in “Trending Topics.”
articles.abstract: Accused of political bias, the company offered details on how human editors and algorithms choose what appears — or doesn’t appear — in “Trending Topics.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, the largest social media network, published internal editorial guidelines on Thursday, the company’s latest attempt to rebut accusations that it is politically biased in the news content it shows on the pages of its 1.6 billion users.

articles.headline: Once Again, Thieves Enter Swift Financial Network and Steal
articles.snippet: Investigators are still trying to solve the $81 million cyberheist from the central bank of Bangladesh in February.
articles.abstract: Investigators are still trying to solve the $81 million cyberheist from the central bank of Bangladesh in February.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thieves have again found their way into what was thought to be the most secure financial messaging system in the world and stolen money from a bank. The crime appears to be part of a broad online attack on global banking.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Chief Fund-Raiser Heads Straight for Las Vegas
articles.snippet: Steven Mnuchin, a hedge fund veteran himself, starts calling on big-money donors at a hedge fund conference gilded with Trump supporters.
articles.abstract: Steven Mnuchin, a hedge fund veteran himself, starts calling on big-money donors at a hedge fund conference gilded with Trump supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Less than a week after being recruited by Donald J. Trump to be his campaign fund-raiser, Steven Mnuchin did not waste any time looking for big-money donors.

articles.headline: New President of Brazil, Michel Temer, Signals More Conservative Shift
articles.snippet: Mr. Temer’s first pick for science minister was a creationist, and he is the first Brazilian leader in decades to have no women in his cabinet.
articles.abstract: Mr. Temer’s first pick for science minister was a creationist, and he is the first Brazilian leader in decades to have no women in his cabinet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The new Brazilian president’s first pick for science minister was a creationist. He chose a soybean tycoon who has deforested large tracts of the Amazon rain forest to be his agriculture minister. And he is the first leader in decades to have no women in his cabinet at all.

articles.headline: U.S. Directs Public Schools to Allow Transgender Access to Restrooms
articles.snippet: The letter to school districts does not have the force of law. But it contains an implicit threat of possible lawsuits or a loss of federal aid.
articles.abstract: The letter to school districts does not have the force of law. But it contains an implicit threat of possible lawsuits or a loss of federal aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is planning to issue a sweeping directive telling every public school district in the country to allow transgender students to use the bathrooms that match their gender identity.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Apple Puts $1 Billion in Didi, a Rival to Uber in China
articles.snippet: The investment gives the tech giant a big stake in the top ride-hailing service in China, where the iPhone maker has otherwise struggled.
articles.abstract: The investment gives the tech giant a big stake in the top ride-hailing service in China, where the iPhone maker has otherwise struggled.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple invested $1 billion in Didi Chuxing, China’s biggest ride-hailing service, moving for the first time into on-demand transportation in one of the largest-ever strategic investments by the iPhone maker.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: In College Essays About Money, Echoes of Parents’ Attitudes
articles.snippet: Among the best essays college applicants sent us this year are ones featuring an artist father, an affluent suburb and a frugal Dominican family.
articles.abstract: Among the best essays college applicants sent us this year are ones featuring an artist father, an affluent suburb and a frugal Dominican family.
articles.lead_paragraph: We grown-ups often assume that children are oblivious to our money talk, ignorant of our budget woes and uninterested in how adults make financial decisions. Better to protect them from all that for as long as possible, right?

articles.headline: Apple’s $1 Billion Investment May Ease Ties With China
articles.snippet: The investment in the Didi Chuxing ride-hailing app enlarges the American giant’s Asian footprint as it comes under greater scrutiny from Beijing.
articles.abstract: The investment in the Didi Chuxing ride-hailing app enlarges the American giant’s Asian footprint as it comes under greater scrutiny from Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A $1 billion investment by Apple in a Chinese ride-hailing app is a rounding error for the Silicon Valley giant, which generates about $4 billion in profit every month and has $233 billion in cash and securities in the bank.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Alan Rusbridger, Once Guardian’s Celebrated Editor, Severs Ties With It
articles.snippet: Mr. Rusbridger, lauded as one of the finest journalists of his generation, gave up a plum role at the organization’s parent after a falling out with its new leaders.
articles.abstract: Mr. Rusbridger, lauded as one of the finest journalists of his generation, gave up a plum role at the organization’s parent after a falling out with its new leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Alan Rusbridger retired last year after two decades as the editor of The Guardian, he was lauded as one of the finest journalists of his generation, having transformed a midsize British newspaper into an international digital media giant. He racked up a string of investigative scoops and made the organization a darling of left-leaning readers around the English-speaking world.
articles.byline: By Prashant S. Rao and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: Donald Trump on His Tax Rate: ‘It’s None of Your Business’
articles.snippet: Insisting that “people will learn nothing” from his tax returns, Donald J. Trump said that he didn’t believe voters had a right to see them and that his tax rate was “none of your business.”
articles.abstract: Insisting that “people will learn nothing” from his tax returns, Donald J. Trump said that he didn’t believe voters had a right to see them and that his tax rate was “none of your business.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Once again thumbing his nose at a time-honored tradition, Donald J. Trump said Friday that he does not believe voters have a right to see his tax returns, and he insisted it was “none of your business” when pressed on what tax rate he pays.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Lending Club, a Story Stock That Skimped on the Details
articles.snippet: Lack of information undermined investors’ confidence in Lending Club’s prospects as doubts about the peer-to-peer lending industry emerged, causing shares to plummet.
articles.abstract: Lack of information undermined investors’ confidence in Lending Club’s prospects as doubts about the peer-to-peer lending industry emerged, causing shares to plummet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The recent tribulations of Lending Club, a former highflying “peer to peer” lender, provide an object lesson for both companies and their investors: When it comes to financial disclosures, less is definitely not more.

articles.headline: Confined to Nursing Homes, but Longing (and Ready) for Home
articles.snippet: Some states are falling short in increasing the share of Medicaid dollars spent on providing support that would allow disabled people to live at home.
articles.abstract: Some states are falling short in increasing the share of Medicaid dollars spent on providing support that would allow disabled people to live at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marvin L. Dawkins was a 53-year-old AT&T manager when a blocked blood vessel left him paralyzed. It took 11 years, one lawsuit, repeated tangles over Medicaid rules — and a chance meeting on a church van — before he could extract himself from a nursing home outside Baltimore.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas, Sheri Fink and Mitch Smith
